dialogues.text: I understand, Cynthia and thank you for the offer. I'll find a place. Now go ahead and give the Cowboy a yodel and get back to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, but you don't know what you're missing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Git along little dowgie and call me back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam hangs up and seems to sag, cupping his forehead and with his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam, in his Porsche, makes his way up the canyon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam feeling like a fool drives up the dark, winding cany road. As he nears the top of the canyon the residential a gives way to desert brush. The road winds steeply up to a dark dead end where an old barn and stable sit. Adam park a little dirt lot and walk up past the barn to the corral His eyes grow accustomed to the dark and he.looks about. one is around. There's only a light wind and a few twinkl stars in the sky above. Suddenly some bare bulbs hanging the corral gate flare up. Adam hears a noise in the brightness and turns. There walking toward him into the l is the Cowboy - dressed in clean blue denim jeans, well-o unscuffed, beautifully engraved cowboy boots, a red embroidered ivory buttoned cowboy shirt complete with str tie. Atop the Cowboy's head is a 10 X white Stetson. The Cowboy is smiling warmly as he approaches. He stops in fr of Adam and begins to speak with a true, slow Western dra

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure want to thank ya for drivin' all the way up to see me from that Beverly Hills Hotel. ADAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem. What's on your mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well now, here's a man who wants to get right to it. Kinda anxious to get to it are ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man's attitude ... a man's attitude goes some ways toward how a man's life will be. Is that somethin' you agree with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now... did you answer cause you thought that's what I wanted to hear or did you think about what I said and answer cause you truly believe that to be right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree with what you said...truly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That a man's attitude determines to a large extent how his life will be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So since you agree I guess you could be a person who does not care about the good life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, just stop for a little second and think about it. Will ya do that for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You're too busy being a smart aleck to be thinkin'. Now I want ya to think and quit bein' such a smart aleck. Can ya do that for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look ... where's this going? What do you want me to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's sometimes a buggy. How many drivers does a buggy have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So let's just say I'm drivin' this buggy and you fix your attitude and you can ride along with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I know a few things. I know you have had a rough day. You're probably thinkin' I don't know the half of it, but in actual fact I know every part of it. The business of gittin' thrown off your movie, the heartache of seeing your wife with another man... losin' access to that precious film vault...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... realizin' you don't have hardly a nickel to your name and then add on to that the sickenin' feeling some men are gonna catch you and hurt you bad for bustin' their vehicle. Some days are like that. They are rough, but what will tomorrow bring? Will it be better than today? The same ... or worse? A lot of that is up to us individually. Up to us and our attitude. When the Castigliane brothers said "This is no longer your film," they meant it, but they didn't mean you were not going to direct it. I want you to go back to work tomorrow. You were re-casting the lead actress anyway ... audition many girls for the part. When you see the girl that was shown to you earlier today, you will say " This is the girl." The rest of the cast can stay- that is up to you, but that lead girl is not up to you. Now, you will see me one more time if you do good. You will see me two more times if you do bad. Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cowboy turns and walks until he is engulfed in darkne Through the darkness Adam hears the sound of a car door opening and closing, then another opening and closing and then the sound of the car driving away. Adam walks up in direction the Cowboy took, but he sees no sign of a car n any dust nor any road. He goes back down past the barn an stables to his car. There standing by his Porsche is the Cowboy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You thinkin' this'll work out, cause I was thinkin' it just might.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good then, but, just in case, that bank's gonna stay closed a bit longer. You understand that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, this is the last time I see you then unless I do bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, this one doesn't count. It's part of the original one. So then ... until we meet again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam gets in his car and drives off leaving the Cowboy smiling behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the rays of the rising sun falling on the huge let of the HOLLYWOOD SIGN and the hills surrounding it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Rita's face as we hear Betty off screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I came back. I thought that's what you wanted."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moving back we realize that the girls are acting out Bett audition scene. Rita is reading her lines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "My parents are right upstairs! They think you've left..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I can call them... I can call my dad... "

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "You're playing a dangerous game here. If you're trying to blackmail me... it's not going to work."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "You know what I want...it's not that difficult."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Get out! Get out before I call my dad ... he trusts you ... your his best friend. This will be the end of everything... "

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "What about you? What will your dad think about you?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Stop! Just Stop! That's what you said from the beginning. If I tell what happened... they'll arrest you and put you in jail, so get out of here before..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty pulls a table knife out from behind her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty mimes with moving fingers tears flowing from her ey

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cry, cry, cry, and then I say with big emotion, "I hate you... I hate us both!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty drops the kitchen knife and both girls start laughi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty mimes tapping a cigarette in a cigarette holder ala Dietrich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the move Coco is just bringing her cigarette in its ho up to her painted red lips. The phone is ringing and she' crossing the room to answer it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello ... Ruthie... How's the great up north? ... Oh, I'm sorry to hear it ... what? Well, I haven't seen her if she's in there. Now, Ruthie there's nothing to worry about. I saw Betty last night and she was just fine. Yes, and I gave them to her. She's a real nice kid, Ruthie. Now stop worrying, will ya. I'll go over and have a look around. I will. I've got the production office number. I'll find you. Now keep your socks on up there and take lots of "C." Goodbye honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coco puts down the receiver with a long sigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty and Rita are sitting on the leather couch having so coffee. The front door to the apartment is open and sunli is pouring in through the screen door. Betty looks at her watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no wonder I'm starving. I'm going to fix a sandwich. You want one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to eat something. You're just nervous about going over to see if you're Diane Selwyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita just looks at her. Betty starts for the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suit yourself. I'll share mine with you if you change your mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty goes into the kitchen. Suddenly there's a knock on screen door and Coco peers in, seeing Rita on the couch. Rita looks up ... panicked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty comes out from the kitchen and sees the situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I see you outside a minute Betty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty walks past Rita, pats her on the shoulder and goes outside to see Coco who has moved away to wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The screen door slams. Coco and Betty face each other clo out of earshot of Rita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wants to know who's staying in her apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just for a night or two, until she finds her own place. I tried to explain that to Aunt Ruth, but the connection was bad and her plane was leaving and she got it all mixed up. I kept telling her it was my friend and she kept saying she didn't know any Ritas ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty lifts her eyes to Coco's. Direct, clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coco...she's very nice. We went to school together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I guess your Grandpa and Grandma know her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really. I met her in junior college and she was from this other town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coco looks hard into Betty's innocent face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can call my grandparents ... I'm sure they'd tell you that I don't lie and I sure wouldn't allow a stranger to invade my Aunt Ruth's apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey... I was married to a director for thirty years. He had an uncanny ability to read people. Maybe some of it rubbed off on me or maybe I had it all along ... you're a good kid... What you're telling me is a load of horse - pucky but it comes from a good place. I'll trust you to sort this out. Now I'm not going against Ruth. She's got enough to worry about up there in Canada. If she asks- I'm going to say everything is okay, and you make sure it is. (Coco places her hand on Betty's shoulder and squeezes it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you need any help you know where to find me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty puts her hand on Coco's shoulder and gives her a squeeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're really something Coco...thank you. COCO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't make me out to be a sucker. Louise Bonner says there's trouble in there. You remember last night. Sometimes she's wrong, but if there is trouble - get rid of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coco turns and walks away. Betty studies her and thinks about what she said before turning and going back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty enters through the screen door. Rita studies her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is everything all right? Is it bad for you that I'm here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything is A-okay, but I've gotta get that sandwich!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On her way to the kitchen she checks her watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I've got an audition in one hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detective Neal Domgaard throws two wallets down on the de in front of Detective Harry McKnight. Harry pauses in the middle of a large bite of grilled cheese sandwich with ba and tomato. He looks down and studies the wallets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DETECTIVE HARRY MCKNIGHT (biting in and chewing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Handstitched Italian. Filled with phony credit cards ... off the two guys in the Caddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... just .... Dr. Scott's got 'im. You remember Dr.Scott.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well he said...  you know in his way... you know what I mean? Besides the guy gettin' rolled up under the kids car which busted him up pretty bad, there was this little knife-like torn piece of metal, you know, off the car body, rolled out and slid up through this guy's neck and just kinda slit his aorta, you know, but they didn't find it right away, so the guy's losin' a lot of blood, you know, to the brain - all this time cause it was just like this thin little puncture wound on the surface of his neck that kinda sealed itself, he said, while inside the aorta is bleedin' pretty steady all that time. So, Dr. Scott's laughin' you know like he does 'cause he knows we want to talk to this guy. He's laughin' you know and shakin'... Son of a bitch couldn't stop laughin'... It was kinda contagious 'cause pretty soon we were all laughin'...the nurse was laughin'. You know how he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope, not yet. Their fingerprints don't match up anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DETECTIVE HARRY MCKNIGHT (another big bite - chewing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah ... and they both use the same address.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty is coming out of Aunt Ruth's apartment. She calls back in to Rita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope I'm back in a couple of hours. Don't drink all the coke. (we hear laughter from inside and Rita call out.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I get back I'll have the cab waiting, so be ready to go. RITA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty closes the door and heads across the courtyard. She knocks on Coco's door and in a moment Coco answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right gorgeous. Something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. I'm on my way to my audition. Before I go I wanted to ask you if you could remember the man's name ... Aunt Ruthie's friend who helped put this together. It completely went out of my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His name's Wally Brown .... great guy. Been in the business since forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks Coco. It'd be so embarrassing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw! He wouldn't have cared. Just give him a good performance and he'll be happy and I've got a feeling you'll do just that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks Coco. I'll let you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get going. You don't want to be late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty takes off through the iron gates and Coco smiles as watches her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty is wide-eyed and filled with awe at something she i seeing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cab pulls up to the gate. Betty pays the driver and g out. She-stands for a moment staring at a dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks through the gate and as she goes is stopped by PARAMOUNT GUARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where do we think we're going, Miss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who are we auditioning for today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And do we know which of the fifty-seven buildings Wally Brown is in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, now we've got to figure that out first don't we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr.Wallace Brown is in the Executive Building on the second floor. We want to go in and turn right at the first street. Then we want to walk three blocks down past Stage 17 to the white Executive Building. Once we're on the second floor the receptionist will take us from there. Now do we have name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see if we have a pass for Betty Elms ... and we do. Here we go. And good luck Miss. Elms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you... thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty finishes climbing some stairs and crosses to the receptionist. She hands over her pass. The receptionist looks at it, hands it back to Betty and points down the h to her left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty walks down the long corridor past several offices. door to office 43 is open when she arrives and she enters large sitting room with a receptionist at a desk off to o side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Betty Elms. I'm here to audition for... Mr. Brown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Perfect timing. Have a seat and I'll get Mr. Brown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The receptionist stands, walks to a door, knocks twice, t enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She closes the door behind her and Betty is alone in the sitting room. She sits on a couch and looks at the old movie posters covering all four walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a moment the same door opens again and an elderly, distinguished looking gentleman WALLY BROWN comes out smiling. Betty stands up immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Wally Brown. Your Aunt is a very dear friend of mine so it's particularly nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very pleased to meet you. WALLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in. I'd like you to meet everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they walk into Wally's office...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took the liberty of inviting an extra person to see your audition. She saw your resume picture and was very interested in meeting you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside Wally's office several people rise out of chairs w Wally enters with Betty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty Elms this is Jack Taft, my assistant, Jimmy Katz who we've already cast for the part of "Chuck". He'll be doing the scene with you. This is Julie Chadwick and Bob Brooker, the director, and our surprise guest is Sarah James. We couldn't afford her to cast our picture, but as casting agents go she's the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why thank you, Wally. Hello Betty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicki, a very stylish, thin girl with black cat-eyed glas nods coolly to Betty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is Martha, Martha Johnson, who you met out front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty nervously smiles to the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. Shall we get to it? Would you like a water or a coffee before we begin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty's hands are beginning to sweat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then, take a seat everyone. Betty why don't you join Jimmy and we'll play the scene. Is there anything you'd like to say Bob... something to Betty before they begin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty stops on her way across to Jimmy and looks to Bob t director.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No ... it's not a contest, see, the two of them with themselves, so don't play it for real until it gets real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty doesn't know what to say. She catches Sarah's assistant, Nicki, rolling her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty continues walking toward Jimmy who opens his arms t her as she approaches. He's old enough to be her father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just tell me where it hurts, baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to play this one close, Bob. Like it was with that girl, what's her name, with the black hair. That felt good. Whaddya think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty looks from Jimmy to Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'd be good, Jimmy. Just don't rush that line again. I told you... the line where you say, "Before what?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was playin' off 'em. They say, "They'll arrest you"... and stuff like that.. "put you in jail"... they say it like that. They all say it the same way, so I react like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah ... Betty. You don't rush it. I don't rush it. We play it close, just like in the movies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy reaches out and puts his arm around Betty and bring her in against his pot belly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad's best friend goes to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy smiles as he brings Betty a little closer. She is trying to concentrate through the nervousness and Jimmy's breath. There is a silence as Jimmy looks her in the eyes Everyone in the room is looking Betty in the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty and Jimmy start the scene. It is very difficult for Betty as Jimmy has her in an absurd clench now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came back. I thought that's what you wanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy plays this with a big lecherous smile. He gives the last part of the line across her cheek up to her ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty uses the anger of this line to push herself away fr Jimmy. Jimmy reaches out and grabs her wrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty pulls her hand away and stands her ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My parents are right upstairs! They think you've left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy smiles broadly and moves again toward Betty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can call them... I can call my dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs Betty by the wrist again and pulls her in to him He puts his hand on her waist and it accidently slips and keeps going down her hips. He jerks his hand back. Betty looks down and sees Jimmy's hand hovering above her thigh Betty takes her hand and gently presses down on Jimmy's h She slowly looks up with the most seductive smile. Jimmy lets his hand rest more firmly on her thigh, and squeezes thigh as he sees her smile. With his other hand Jimmy gen pulls her closer. Something has started coming over Betty and she catches the drift of this scene in a different wa She's surprising herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're playing a dangerous game here. if you're trying to blackmail me... it's not going to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy now surprises himself. He becomes almost tender and genuinely worked up from the heat coming off Betty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I want...it's not that difficult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the scene should turn to anger from Betty it can't and Betty plays it as she feels it. She stays in very clo to Jimmy - looking him right in the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out... Get out before I call my dad. He trusts you... you're his best friend. (her arms go around him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This will be the end of everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy gets lost. He doesn't know where he is anymore. He can only see Betty's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about you? What will your dad think about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty still playing it in a dreamy whisper... lost in hea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop... just stop! That's what you said from the beginning. If I tell what happened... they'll arrest you and put you in jail, so get out of here before...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JIMMY (caught by her transfixing, sultry eyes, and almost breathless ... he finds himself taking an extra long pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As scripted Betty pretends to pull the knife from behind back, but wraps the knife around behind Jimmy and pulls h into a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy panics and pushes Betty away with his hands on her shoulders as if forcing himself to come out of a trance. finally is able to say his line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then they'd put you in jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As scripted Betty is supposed to cry now and it is very e for her to do this because she's ashamed at how the sex o the scene took her over. Tears begin running down her cheeks. She backs away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate you... I hate us both!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pretends to drop the knife. The scene ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone in the room has become mesmerized by Betty, but soon drift back to reality and begin applauding the performance. Sarah turns to Nicki.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to take her over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty wipes her eyes and turns smiling - still shocked at herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There it was it was! Baby, you got a way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good. Really. I mean it was forced maybe but still humanistic. Yeah, very good, really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, thank you Betty, and I mean that. That was very impressive. You've done your Aunt proud and I'm going to tell her the first chance I get. We'll speak again soon I'm sure, and thank you so much for coming in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty doesn't quite know what to do. She moves to the cen of the room and just stands. Remnants of the scene still staying with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah stands and Nicki stands just after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Wally. I'm sure you all have a lot to talk about. We'll walk Betty out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yes indeed. Our pleasure, Sarah, and don't you be a stranger. We'd love to see you around here again real soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah takes Betty's hand and they go to the door. Betty t back once more and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you again, Mr. Brown. It was nice meeting all of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone nods and waves and Betty is taken out by Sarah a Nicki.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three of them walk down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty's head spins to Sarah. A look of shock and let down her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, not you Betty. You were stellar and I mean that, but poor Wally. He'll never get that picture made. Wally's days were up twenty -years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh god! Jimmy Katz never had a day. Jimmy Katz never had a minute. Poor Wally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty finds herself getting a little upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They seem very nice to me, and Wally... Mr. Brown is a very close friend of my Aunt's, so. . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Settle down, Betty. Don't get me wrong. I love Wally. I ought to. I was married to him for ten years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty does another shocked head turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I love actors, all actors, Jimmy Katz included. We just get a little catty sometimes. Now we want to take you across the way and introduce you to a director who's a head above the rest. He's got a project that you would kill!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the word 'kill' Betty turns to her once again with a questioning look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Knock it right out of the park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see what looks like a recording studio right out of th 1960's. We're looking through a plate of glass. A blonde girl is standing at a vintage microphone. Behind her are three back-up male vocalists dressed in three tone, shiny 60's suits. We hear strings soar up and the blonde girl begins to sing SIXTEEN REASONS by Connie Stevens. The mal vocalists backing her up flawlessly. We move back and realize we are on a movie set inside a s stage. A screen test is being shot of the girl and as we continue moving back we see the director Adam Kesher surrounded by his crew. Behind them there are many people standing, eating, watching, working. The stage is full an bustling. The song plays loudly over. Sarah and Nicki bri Betty into this scene through a giant stage door. A guard mimes for them to be quiet as they approach the set. The song continues to play over. As Sarah leads Betty up close Adam turns and his eyes fal the beautiful face of Betty Elms. Sensing something Betty turns and sees Adam. They each seem to feel the thrill of the thunderbolt, but each embarrassed to stare longer tha they already have turn back and watch the girl finish the song. ADAM (calling out through an electronic megaphone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets out of his chair and walks into the set - up to t blonde girl. He shakes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you very much, Carol. It was really great of you to come in. I know how busy you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, man, are you kidding? I love this script! Where do I sign?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look... I love you, but there's no way they're gonna let me cast this thing until I've seen everyone. I'll let you know as soon as I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you will ... cause my manager's gonna bug you day and night ... me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be my pleasure. Now, get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you're just so cruel... don't forget me. I'm the girl that's going to play this part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam turns and goes back out of the set onto the stage fl He looks around. He sees Betty being introduced by Sarah some of the studio executives. He goes over to his Assist Director and looks down at the man's notepad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank speaks into his walkie-talkie headset. The sound of voice can be heard in several locations throughout the st

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam looks up - a beautiful blonde steps into the set in front of the microphone. IT IS THE GIRL! The back-up singers step in behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The strings soar up and Camilla Rhodes begins to sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the set Betty hears the song again and turns and watch Once again her eyes find Adam as his eyes are finding her This time Adam turns away. He watches Camilla for a momen She is passable, but not spectacular. Adam reaches out an pulls Hank over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cindy ... Adam wants to see Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam continues to watch Camilla Rhodes sing. JASON GOLDWY a tall sixty year old silver-haired man, comes through th crowd and stops at Adam's side. He looks down at Adam, bu Adam continues watching Camilla Rhodes. Jason follows Ada gaze and he watches Camilla sing then turns back to Adam. Adam slowly looks up right into Jason's eyes - wondering much Jason knows, but Jason's face doesn't give away a th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you want to tell me something, Adam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that moment Ray, having overheard, comes to Jason's si He smiles at Adam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the room Betty panics when she looks at her watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh ... oh...I have to be somewhere. I promised a friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She quickly shakes Sarah's and Nicki's hands saying, "I'm sorry, I'm sorry" and runs off like Cinderella.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adam turns and sees her running off out of his world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris Isaak's song "Except The New Girl" segues in over Connie Stevens and plays as Adam, Sarah and Nicki watch B disappear out the sound stage door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris Isaak song "Except The New Girl" continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An idling cab sits waiting with back door open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris Isaak song segues to the sounds of a blues saxophon

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty and Rita come out of Aunt Ruth's apartment. Betty i laughing, pulling on Rita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mom. There's nothing to be afraid of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the courtyard CORNELL DUMONT, a strikingly handsom young black musician, is on his balcony playing the saxophone. He stops playing when he sees the girls. He stands and looks as if recognizing someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty and Rita stop and look up, shielding their eyes fro the sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry... I forget your name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Well, I haven't seen Sol lately. Tell him to come by the club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita nods ... biting her lip. Cornell smiles and picks up sax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins to blow some sweet jazz that flows smooth as sy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita hurriedly starts for the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty follows Rita through the gate to the waiting cab. T get in and the cab pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty reaches and gently grabs Rita's shoulder. She speak firmly but quietly so the cab driver won't hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you ask him? Sol knows you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I don't know, Sol. I never heard of Sol. I'd just get in trouble. That's why we shouldn't go see about Diane Selwyn... it's better not to get in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to get in trouble. You're going to find out who you are. Finding out who you are gets you out of trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita thinks about this silently then begins to worry and doubt all over again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty holds the slip of paper with the address in her han She turns back and forth watching the buildings on both s of the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita watches out of the window pensively as the cab moves Sierra Bonita. They near a modern apartment compound of bungalows and duplexes almost hidden in the trees and vegetation. A smooth stucco wall surrounds the complex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita shakes her head..no. Rita is looking at a black car parked down the street facing 2590. She discerns two men sitting in the front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? What do you see?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those men in front, in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep going. Go around to the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty gets Rita out of the cab and pays the driver, who t drives away. The girls go through a rear gate and enter t complex walking along a curving concrete walk. This leads them to an intersection where a registry is printed on a rough hewn wooden plaque. They scan the list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both look around the various doors near them. Betty spots a sign which says, behind an arrow, bungalows #10 through #20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They set off down another sidewalk toward Bungalow #12. A they near it and actually can see it just ahead they pass chainlink service gate to the alley. Standing in the alle a man in a dark suit wearing sunglasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both girls dive for the bushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man in the black suit turns reacting to the noise and motion. Both girls are trying to catch their breath and s as still and quiet as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peering through the bushes they see the man still looking their direction. Suddenly he turns and smiles at somethin to his left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hurries off, but soon returns carrying two heavy suitcases, followed by an older woman in a yellow dress. Both Betty and Rita crawl further forward. They see the l and realize that the man they were afraid of is an ordina limousine driver just going about his work. The girls sta up, relieved and a little embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, I told you there was nothing to be afraid of!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go up to Bungalow #12 and stand for a moment facing front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty doesn't listen to Rita. She knocks strongly on the door. They stand waiting. There's no answer so Betty knoc again harder. They wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the door opens. An attractive MIDDLE-AGED WOMAN stands before them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I switched apartments with her. She's in #17. Just walk down that way. It's just to the right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman seems to be looking now at Rita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's kind of hidden by the foliage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty and Rita start to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hasn't been around for a few days ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well ... we'll leave her a note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go with you. She's still got some of my stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone rings from inside her bungalow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh ... go ahead. I've got to get that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman hurries back inside and closes the door. Betty Rita quickly move up the walkway toward Bungalow #17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita, still fighting her fear doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reach Bungalow #17. It's set back beneath tall bushe and an old Eucalyptus tree. The front door is in deep sha Without even looking at Rita Betty knocks quickly. There' answer. She knocks again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls drift off to the side of the bungalow. Betty tr to see in the windows. She tries a window and to her surp it opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon help me in. I'll open the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty jumps up and catches her knees on the siding, her h through the open window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita reluctantly pushes and Betty is in. As she closes th window ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita walks around to the front door and gets there just a Betty opens it. Betty has her hand over her mouth and nos

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if you want to come in here or not. There's some kind of horrible smell like... something...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita is compelled to go in and as the door clicks shut sh reacts to the smell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty begins to go through the bungalow and Rita follows. All the blinds are closed and the curtains drawn. They mo slowly, looking around at everything as they go. Betty lo to Rita to see if any of this is something she remembers. Rita looks as though she's walking in a trance. Through t half light they move deeper into the bungalow to a corrid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Middle-Aged Woman is just shutting the door to her bungalow. She walks quickly in the direction of Bungalow #17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty and Rita are moving down the corridor. They pass a small room and look in at a couch, wardrobe and make-up table. They move on down the corridor to a door which is almost closed. Betty touches the door and it seems to swi open on its own. They enter the room and stop cold. A scr starts to build inside Rita. Before them is a dead woman lying on a bed. Great chunks of mattress are standing upr having been ripped and torn by shotgun blasts. A dried se blood surrounds the bloated, gray body of the woman. The scream comes out of Rita as a force propelling her to loo closer. Betty lunges after Rita, her eyes also not able t leave the sight. She covers Rita's mouth with her hand an brings her close. The scream is stifled by Betty's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the silence that follows, knocking can be heard. Betty freezes and keeps Rita quiet with her hand still placed o her mouth, but she can't stop Rita's violent shaking nor horror in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Middle-Aged Woman backs away from the front door, loo around at bungalow #17. She's not sure if she has heard something or not. She wonders, then turns and goes back t her bungalow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as she has disappeared the door to Bungalow #17 flie open and Rita, followed closely behind by Betty, runs wit look of horror directly toward us until her tortured face fills the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great sobs, almost hysterical, wrack Rita's body as she b over the sink, scissoring into her long, dark hair with a frenzy. There is a loud sound of the scissors cutting dee through many strands of hair. Betty's is rushing to her - her hands reach tenderly, but firmly for Rita's hand hold the scissors. She keeps her from cutting and moves closer whispering in Rita's ear. Rita can't stop crying, but let Betty hold her. Music changes ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita... I know what you're doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what you have to do, but let me do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita turns and looks up at Betty, her eyes red with cryin Betty pulls her up facing her. Rita lets Betty take the scissors. They look into each other's eyes. Betty gently strokes Rita's cheek, wiping away some tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Panning slowly across we see on the bathroom counter vari open bottles, used Q-tips, towels, combs, a brush, a bowl and lots of long strands of cut black hair. We continue moving up to an empty mirror and eerie music builds. The reflection of the new Rita moves into the mirror. She has short, beautiful blonde hair, blonde eyebrows and no make Betty's reflection comes in beside Rita's. They stare at new Rita in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We move off the door of Aunt Ruth's apartment and crane slowly up to the apartment above hers - WILKINS - the one with the wayward dog. We move closer to Wilkins' apartmen and as we move in we hear a phone ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilkins still in his pajamas, bathrobe and slippers from morning slouches in an enormous stuffed chair and matchin ottoman, surrounded by piles of papers and coffee cups. H Jack Russell Terrier wakes and stands at the sound of the phone ringing on a side table next to Wilkins. Wilkins co out of a deep thought and picks up the receiver as he run his hand through strange, matted tufts of dirty blonde ha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. Adam. How's it going? No, it's okay. Yeah, I'm working, but... they wanted this script a week ago. What? What's wrong with your house? The poolman? Sure, you can have the couch. No, it's no problem..it's just I gotta ... I gotta work. Any chance you could bring some food. No, I got plenty of money - I just haven't gone out for awhile. Groovy man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy and I'll be glad to see you. No, no, no, he's got plenty of food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita has just taken the hatbox from the closet shelf and setting it on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty is sitting on the bed opposite. Rita opens the hatb and removes her purse. She opens the purse and takes out money. She sits down on the bed and while staring at the money she thinks of what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been so good to me ... now we know why ... why I was so afraid. We know what kind of trouble I'm in. I shouldn't... ask you... I only have this to offer. I'll give you this if I can stay here for awhile. I don't know what else to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty moves across the bed to the side of Rita. She puts arm around Rita and holds her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita... I want you to stay here and you don't have to give me that money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. We shouldn't touch that money. We don't know about that money. That might be dangerous money. You have to start all over again. You look like a brand new person and you can be a brand new person... whoever you want to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sounds kind of nice ... being somebody brand new.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, let's introduce the brand new you to Hollywood. We haven't seen the roof garden yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls come out the front door ... Betty leading and p a much happier Rita along with her. They half run across courtyard to stone steps under an Ivy covered eave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls race up the stone steps toward us. Soon their w blown, smiling faces fill the screen as they look out. Th before them are the lights of Hollywood with silhouetted palms, slow-moving theater kleig lights, and floating abo it all the giant sign in the hills reading HOLLYWOOD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here I am Hollywood! My name's Betty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here I am Hollywood! My name is ... Rita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look out, maybe waiting for an answer blowing in the Santa Ana wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We move in to the pile of money next to Rita's purse. Pas that we move down inside Rita's purse. We see the Blue Ke and move closer to it until it fills the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We drift along the red bricks past the payphone, along th wall until we come to the corner. Slowly we round the cor and move to a dark alley. There amongst the dumpsters and trash cans is the dark silhouette of a figure. We move cl to the figure. It is the bum and the bum sits. We move closer and the bum's face fills the screen. It's face is black with fungus. It's eyes turn and they seem to be red
